element_texts.text: Completed

Sac & Fox
Agency
Okla. T.
Nov. 22. 1900.
My dear Uncle.
There are two
only descendants of
Black hawk living
near here two brothers
one is 48 years old the
other 60 and Black hawk
was their Grandfather
The one 48 is sitting
for me in genuine
Sac & Fox costume
I had the worst time
to get him he was
so awfully superstitious 
finally he consented
Completed

to sit his face is all
painted up and he
wears on his head
a thing made from
Wild Turkey whiskers
that have always been
worth a horse each.
He is fixed up like
the Sac & Fox Indians
I saw in that large
book of yours the
colored plates, He
says he thinks his
brother will sit for
me. I have had quite
a talk with Keokuk
through the interpreter
Completed

(3)
and what you
wrote me about him
is true. His wife is
half white and half
Sac during the Blackhawk
War her Mother swam
the Mississippi River
on horseback with the 
present Keokuks wife
on her back.
Keokuk likes to talk of
old times he is a fine
man very religious &
thoroughly trustworthy
and highly respected.
his house is as clean &
nice as any white mans.
Were these Sac & Fox
Indians the ones that
Completed

lived around Big Foot?
And did they name 
the place?
In my travels I have
seen or heard of an
Indian named Big foot.
The Pottawatomies are
around here also the
Iowa Indians & a distinct
tribe I may paint
some of them
I have moved my 
quarters and am now 
better fixed have a 
nice room to sleep in
The only trouble have a
feather mattress with
Completed

(5) about one fourth
enough feathers in it
The best beds I have
had to sleep in have
been in the hay in the barns with
blankets under me
& the nice new mown
hay made a fine bed.
I am having better luck 
here than anticipated
I stopped work on
Keokuks other picture
as was afraid
Blackhawks grand son
would go home.
You may not like
Keokuks picture on
account of his being
dressed in his Sunday
clothes but I had to
11-22-00
Completed

paint him that way or
not at all,
I may go to Darlington
& then to Anadarka
from here There are
several good Chiefs at
both places hav'nt
painted.
I am gaining a little
right along the game is
so plentiful here that
I can go half a mile
& get game enough to
keep myself supplied
with good eating
Saturday eve" three
of us are going
Completed

(7) hunting to be gone
until Sunday night
We may get some Deer
Did you get the
Nov number of Brush
& Pencil? I wrote an 
article about Indians
in Art and have read
a nice complimentary
letter on it from an
Indian man out
West.
Your affectionate
nephew.
Elbridge
Completed

Sac & Fox.
Agency.
Okla. T.
Nov. 27. 1900.
My dear Uncle
Guess I told you
I had changed my
quarters and am much
better fixed. I keep my
self in game as there
is such fine shooting 
here but am getting
tired of eating Quail.
I finished another
picture of Keokuk to
day and got a good
picture of him.
Am painting now
Completed

an Ottawa Indian
in full Ottawa costume
face painted etc.
And Today I engaged
an Iowa Indian to
sit for me a Chief
They are a distinct
type by them selves
different features altogether 
from any Indians
I have seen he is to
bring his costume.
I never heard of the 
Iowas until came
here There are 24 or 25
different tribes in
Oklahoma Territory.
4218
Completed

(3) There are also some
Pottawatomies here.
You have often told me
I ought to have a
guardian in a joking
way but I would be
better off if I had had
a guardian since have
been painting Indians
I would have managed
those Indian reproductions
different. I want to
ask you Uncle Ed
if I have a right
to examine the books
pertaining to my account
on the Indian reproductions
so far I have taken
their word for the 
business done and I
11-27-00
Completed

hav'nt got out of it scarcely
$1000.00. It seems to me
I have a right to have
a man look over their
books as it is now
I have only their word
and statements sent
me which doesnt look
like good business to 
me. I should have made
a good thing out of those
reproductions as it 
stands now They have
the money and I the 
reputation. I wish you
would advise me.
How I wish I was a
Completed

(5)
good business man.
I could have been pretty
well fixed now. but
I never heard of an Artist
that was worth any
thing at business if
he was he was a poor
Artist.
But I am thankful I
control the original pictures
and I have something
like 125 now are
worth a good deal
My next exhibition will
be very interesting on
account of so many
different types.
I will try & visit all 
the different tribes here 
this time.
The profile finished of
11-27-00
Completed

Keokuk today is one of
my very best portraits
His wife is very interesting
I am gaining right along
am not near so nervous.
At one time thought I
had painted my last
Indian but as things
are now I hope to 
get portraits of all the
different tribes in
America.
I received a letter from
Maratta he expects to 
come here soon. He has
finished the Grand
Canon for the Santa Fe
Completed

(7) R.R. wish you could
see it am sure you would
pronounce it the best
thing you have seen of the 
Canon. Mr Higgins thought
so.
I would be better contented
if my wife was with me
she could see that I got
proper food to eat even
if she had to cook it her
self. I have been writing
my experiences among
the Indians and my wife
now is correcting it
and later on am to 
have it published in
book form well illustrated
and am going to have 
the book dedicated to you.
11-27-00
Completed

after my wife has got
it in better shape I will
have some good writer
look it all over and get
it in fine shape before
publishing it. and on
this book I am going to
be sharp am not going
to let some one else have
all the profit.
What do you think of the
idea of the book?
Your affectionate
nephew
Elbridge
Completed

Sac & Fox Agency 12/1/00
Okla. T. 
Dec 1 1900.
My dear Uncle
Yours received 
Just as soon as Blackhawks
grand sons picture is dry enough
will send it with Keokuks to you
by Express. it is one of the very best
pictures I ever painted
I ordered a frame for Keokuks
picture of Thurber will order another
one for Blackhawks so when you
receive the pictures you can take
them there and have framed.
I will get some more good
subjects here from the out look
another Sac & Fox Chief is to sit
for me and I guess I will get
a Shawnee Chief to sit for me also
The present Keokuk is as fine a
man as I ever met thoroughly
honest and a devoted member
Completed

of the church. 
Yes I have lots of sport hunting
I work five hours a day when
I can get Indians to sit for me.
The great trouble is the food these
people dont seem to have serve enough
to eat proper food when they have
so much land to raise vegetables
but I think it is pure lazyiness 
To day I will buy some eggs and
have them cooked. They have plenty of
onions but never cooked them until
I asked them to.
I see Earnest S. Thompson is in 
Chicago lecturing wish you could 
meet him.
There is a tribe of Modoc Indians
in Kansas that I will visit on my
way home They are becoming extinct 
as fast as possible, They belong
to the same tribe in Northern
California, They must have
4218
Completed

been a very warlike people
Am glad to know what tribe
it was that lived around Harvard
The Pottawattomies & Sac & Fox must
have mingled with each other
a good deal in older times as
a Sac & Fox Indian told me
their langague was very similar
that they could converse with each
other easily.
I am getting better right along
slept good last night.
When I am allright again, will be
better than ever in every May.
With love to Aunt Emma
Your devoted nephew
Elbridge.
12-1-00
Completed

Sac & Fox Agency
Okla T.
Dec 5 1900. 12/5/00
My dear Uncle
Yours read" and glad
to hear from you.
I have been waiting now four
days for two Indians to come
that have promised to sit for me. 
one is an Iowa Indian Chief and
the other a Sac & Fox Chief.
Enclose send you a few notes my
wife sent me I had her look
up the Sac & Fox Indians history
and you will see the Sox & Fox
Indians joined band in about 1765 
Yes I ought to have my wife
with me.
I have been thinking seriously
about a tent and regular
camping out fit I could have
a tent arranged so could have a
Completed

Studio in it that is I could have
opaque cloth inside so that the
sun light would've change the light
so that the light would be the same
in the tent whether the sun was
shining or not, a window could
be made to fold up when
traveling and could be fastened
on the tent to work by, my wife
and I could keep house & could
have comfortable cots to sleep on
and the great advantage the tent
could be taken and put up any 
where and we would be independent 
could have healthy wholesome food 
well cooked to eat and then I 
could be right where my subjects 
lived The tent & whole thing could 
be shipped by freight ahead & 
hauled around by wagon.
At the Indian Agencys very few 
of the Indians live right near the
4218
Completed

Agency they generally live from 
two to forty miles away.
At Fort Sill there are several
Chiefs that I never have been able
to get because they never happened
to be at the Fort when I was
as if they did come, didn't have
time to sit as had to return home
Indians like to be followed up
Chief Big Tree a Kiowa Chief of note
lives 20 miles from Ft Sill he
would sit for me but I would have
to go out to his place I never went because
there were no accmadations there
except Indian fare.
What do you think of the tent idea? The
whole thing could be got up for
less than $75.00 and just one
Indian picture would more than
pay for it. I could travel my
12-5-00
Completed

old route all once again and get
Indians couldn't get before
and the living would be so much
cheaper.
I have fun hunting there are
two of the finest hunting dogs here
I ever seen. but i have eaten
so much Quail that it makes me
a little sick to see one.
An Indian made a speech here
Thanksgiving to some Indian school
children which was fine. Today
I asked him if he would write that
speech down I would have it
published and I would send the
speech to you. He is very enthusiastic
over the work I am doing
and is lots of help to me.
Your devoted nephew
Elbridge.
Completed

Sac & Fox Agency
Okla T.
Dec. 12 1900  12/12/00
My dear Uncle
Yours received &
glad to hear from you.
Tomorrow I will send
the two Keokuks pictures
and one of Blackhawks
grand son to Thurber to
be framed. I want them
to let you know when the
pictures arrived so that
you could choose the one
of Keokuk you wished
me is a front view & one
a profile Mr Butler has 
bought me of Keokuk he
will take the one you do
not he wants a picture
Completed

of Blackhawks grandson
so will try and get
him to sit for another
I have been looking now
more than a week waiting
for the Indians to come in
that have promised me is 
to be here sure this week
there has been sickness &
one death among them
& a Chief who was to
come he was delayed by
his sons wife having a
pair of twins.
I have written an article
for the Past which will
be published some Saturday
soon, they have been waiting
for a Sac & Fox picture
I have instructed Mr
Dyer to have me of Keokuks
pictures photographed
4218
Completed

(3)
you might have the one you
select photographed as
I will want it for this
book. I am going to have
the book nicely illustrated
Mc Clures Magazine wrote
me to send the ms to them
and they would publish
it in the Magazine in
parts which would be a
good idea then afterwards
have it published in book
form. Hereafter I am going
to keep my eyes open and
when I see a chance to
make some money out of my
work take advantage of
it. Do you know Uncle Ed
12-12-00
Completed

that unclear I have been
painting Indians which
is only a little over three years if
I had used better judgment
I would have money enough
now to last me the rest
of my life, but I think the
book will take, am going
to have Maratta make the
cover design, it will be a
big job to get the manuscript
in shape for print
but Tot is at work on it
now, she wrote a fine
article for Harpers Weekly 
about White Swan I
painted they gave us
$55.00 for the article &
illustrations The article has
not come out yet but
I think it will soon.
Completed

(5)
I am getting better things
to eat now the woman is 
my kind she does all sh
can I have eggs every
morning now and vegetables
such as potatoes cabbage
turnips & onions so am
all right. I take long
walks every day. Today
have been working on my 
story. When I first commenced
to paint Indians the idea
did not come to me to
write my experience wich
I had thought of it then
and every new tribe I visited
hired an interpreter to be with
me all day and
Completed

all the Indians said about
my work which would be
more interesting. I remember
on Pretty Eagle sat back of
me when I was painting
and Talked and a white
man who understood Crow
was present and he told me
what Pretty Eagle said,
he said that man makes
two or three wipes and
there is an eye etc.
He said he never knew that
a white man could ever
make picture he said a great
many Indians can.
I thought that the
Completed

(7) Pottawattomies & Sac
& Foxes must have mingled
as their language is similar
there is one Pattawattomie
her and some Ottawas
who are very sweet and
intelligent people one of
them is a Minister here
preaches every Sunday.
I think you will prefer
the Profile of Keokuk
to the front view as it
is such as strong resemblance
to Henry Ward Beecher.
Your affectionate
nephew Elbridge.
12-12-00
Completed

Sac & Fox Agency
Okla. T.
Dec 28 1900   12/28/00
My dear Uncle
Mr Dyer wrote me
that you select the front
view of Keokuk and one of
Blackhawks grand son.
I have finished another of
Blackhawks grand son for
Mr Butler and the other
grand son has promised to
sit for me after New Years.
I am now painting a
portrait of the only living
Shawnee Chief he is an old
white headin Indian and 
a fine man in every way
his word is as good as gold
Completed

His white name is Long
Tom Washington he is
called Washington from
his resemblance to Washington
his Indian name is
Chief Lo-waine-wag-she-kah
he probably will sit for
two portraits. I am
gradually getting more
like my self I get pretty
good things to eat now
such as vegetables & eggs
& wild game which is 
plentiful here.
I have been expecting to go
to the Quaw paw Agency
but there are some more
Indians I want to get
here.
I will get the Modocs
at Quaw paw and other
tribes.
4218
Completed

The old Chief am painting
now has quite a history
he has killed 7 white men
they were horse thiefs
His brother was a muted
Chief Big Jim he died
four months ago.
As soon as the picture
is dry enough will send
it and two Kickapous
and one Ottawa will
exhibit the old Chiefs
picture in Art Institute.
I see Maratta has got out
a nice booklet for Santa
Fe R.R.
Wishing you all a 
Happy New Year
Your devoted nephew
Elbridge.
12-28-00
Completed

Sac & Fox Agency 1/2/01
Okla. T.
Jan. 2 - 1901
My dear Uncle
Yours of Dec 31
just received.
The Ottawa I painted
in a good type but he
is not a Chief
I saw him often receiving
your letter and asked
him about the Ottawas
He says a good many
Ottawas are at Quaw paw
Agency some 100 miles
from here in Oklahoma
T. that one Ottawa Chief
is there, there there are
some Ottawas in Canada
Completed

some in Colorado and
a good many in
Michigan and some
scattered in other states
They all are pretty well
civilized There are two
here both speak English
fluently.
Newly are the Ottawa
have a mustache and 
Told they wore a mustache
in older times.
When I go to Quaw paw
will try and get the
Ottawa Chief to sit
for me. I am expecting
the other Blackhawk
grand son in every day
his Indian name translated
is Blackhawk.
4218
Completed

(3) I am quite sure I
can get the Ottawa
Chief to sit for me.
Quaw paw is the home
for the Ottawas in Okla
T.
I finished a good
picture of the only Shawnee
Chief he is a very old
man and won't live long
his hair is whit, had
quite a time to get
hime to sit.
I would like to be
remembered to Dr Favill
With best wishes for
the New Year
Your devoted nephew
Elbridge.
1-2-01
Completed

Sac & Fox Agency 1/3/01
Okla. T.
Jan3 1901
My dear Uncle,
Since writing you
yesterday I find that
there is an Ottawa
Chief here he is an
inherited Chief and a
very smart bright man
his Father was a Chief
so was his Grand Father
and his Great Grand Father
was the noted Chief Pontiac
that Pontiac Mich was
named after. He is to
sit for me tomorrow
in costume and if
Dr Favill wants the
Completed

picture he may have it
He told me his Indians
name but I have forgotten
it, translated means
"Noon day"
He speaks English as
well as any white man
and is a member of the
Baptist Church
Keokuk called to see me
today and I think the
old fellow wants to
sit for another picture.
His picture the one you have
has been photographed
and you can get one of
Thurbers if you wish it.
Your devoted nephew
Elbridge
4218
Completed

P.S. This Ottawa Chiefs
white name is William Her.
and in case Dr Favill
wished to he could correspond
with him and get his whole
history where he was born
etc and all about
his Great Grand Father
Pontiac, He told me it 
was a wish of Pontiac
to always preserve his
name by namming some
of his children Pontiac
and so far that wish has
been adhered to, There is a 
relative here now named
Pontiac after him he is called
Ponty.
1-3-01
Completed

Sac & Fox Agency
Okla. T.
Jan 5 1901
My dear Uncle
Since writing you
I have found out that
the old Chief I painted
whose white name
is Long Tom Washington
is a great grand son
of Tecumseh. This picture
I will send to the
Art Institute This place
seems to have so many
noted descendents.
Am getting a first
picture of Pontiac's decendent
will paint two
portraits of him he
is fixed up in Ottawa costume
Completed

Tecumsehs descendent is
to sit for another pictures
Keokuk was in to see
me again Today and he
wants to sit for another
portrait all dress up
in Sac & Fox costume
he has sent any for
the costume so I am
liable to remain her for
some time I have changed
my room am now sleeping
in same room I work in
which is better as have
a stove in my room &
can take a bath. I caught
an awful cold in the
other room and came near
having pneumonia which
is very prevalient here
4218
Completed

(3) My wife is busy
working on my book.
I received a letter from
Mr Maratta and he thinks
I ought to get some good
Author in Western Stories
to rewrite and finish the
story for me he suggests
Mr. E. Hough who wrote
the girl at the half way
house. The story of the 
cowboy etc etc
Mr Maratta thinks that
my wife would loose
the Western flavor which
is true as she never has
been West
Mr Maratta is to design
the book and cover for
me.
I will look out and see
that I don't get robbed
1-5-01
Completed

in this book and get all
there is due me and I
think it will bring me
in a fair income. of course
I will give you one book
as it is to be dedicated
to you and I am going
to have it worded nice
and let you see it before
it is printed in the book.
Pontiacs descendent says
he will be pleased to 
correspond with Dr Favill
and tell him all about
him self he knows a
good deal of Pontiacs
History which has been
handed down in the
family.
With love to you & Aunt Emma
Your devoted nephew
Elbridge
Completed

Sac & Fox Agency
Okla. T.
Jan 13 1901           1/13/01
My dear Uncle
Your received
If Keokuk sits for
another portrait in costume
you can exchange the one
you now have for it.
I have changed my
mind in regard to the
book will have my wife
write it all as she is
fully capable of doing it
then we wont have to pay
some one else for rewriting
it.
the Sac & Fox Indians
held a counsel in my
room for two day so
Completed

I couldn't work.
Keokuk was the head
speaker he gets very
eloquent. the talk was
translated to the Agent
and it surprised me to
see how these Indians
weighed each subject
and how very careful
they were that the different
problems They had to deal
with were handled so
carefully and what a
lot they had to say
on each subject
One of the things they had
to settle was a white woman
with two children who was
related to the Sac & Fox
and she wanted to draw
annuity money
4218
Completed

(3) but the Indians Told
her she must give absolute
proof that these were her
children so she has to write
back and get the Doctors
proof also proofs in the
Church where they were
Christened etc There an
old lady where Mother
was a Sac & Fox member
to you. the tribe. She knew
Keokuks Father but she
has got to give proof
that will be hard for her
to get to establish her
relation to the Sac & Fox
One Indians got up and
said we all had Mothers
once and they raised us
and were good to us but
none of us here have any
Mothers living and he
1-13-01
Completed

says one must not be
harsh with this old lady
etc. Tomorrow I will
finish Pontiacs grand son
Am getting a good picture
of him in costume.
Haven't heard fro Dr
Favill as yet.
With best wishes
Your devoted nephew
Elbridge.
Completed

Sac & Fox Agency    1/26/01
Okla. T.
Jan 26 1901.
My dear Uncle
I have the picture
finished of the Ottawa
Chief for Dr Favill to
see I sent some more
pictures to Thurber would
like to have you see them
I have been looking
for a good deal waiting
for Indians but I
don't mind it as I
haven't been well
Mr Kimbark who 
has charge of the
Indian plates wants
to sell the 54 plates
Completed

for $?.000 he thinks it
would be a good plan
if some one would buy
the plates and put them
away for some ten
years then bring them
out again.
As things have turned
out with the plates
it would have been better
I think if I never had
allowed them to be
reproduced in colors
but still it has been an
education to the public
and has made me
known pretty well over
the country, whether it
has hurt the side of
Indians pictures is
a question
4218
Completed

(3) The last 21 Indian
plates that were made
was made on this
condition, that if the
Paper Milles Co (Kimbark)
did not buy a certain
number of pictures in a
enough to pay for
the 21 plates the color
type people would use
the plates but in either
case I get my commission
just the same, but the
trouble is the color type
people will use there for
advertising purposes
and if the 54 plates
could all be bought
then they could not use
them.
If I could afford it
I would buy them my
1-26-01
Completed

self and think in ten
years they could be
brought out again with
screens.
I called on Mrs Keokuk
last we" she is a bright
smart woman and knows
a lot of Indian history
that is pertaining to the
Sac & Fox Indians
When do you start for
Europe?
Your devoted nephew
Elbridge.
Completed

HOTEL DE MONT - image
Finest Hotel                      Fine Sample Room
In the Country.                  Accommodations...

         HOTEL
         DE MONT
           MONT HALL, Proprietor.

Seneca, Mo., Feb 2 1901
My dear Uncle
Yours received
It is hard to get the Indians
to take off their lather, the bead
belt around Washington is typical
Shawnee and in older times was
always worn by them. He is a
good sample on account of being
a grand son of Tecumseh and the
only Shawnee Chief living.
The Indian plates will not be
destroyed but probably the color
type people will use them for
advertising purposes.
I have no peony in the plates
at all
Thanks for mentioning my
Indian pictures to Mr. Hacket.
I arrived here last night
and had intended going out to
Ayer MS 120
Completed

the Quaw Paw Agency 4 miles
from here  but I can get the Indians
to come here as well as 
the Hotel is comfortable good
Tables and reasonable in price
have concluded to remain here
I have a Modoc engaged to
come Monday.
The two noted Modocs Chiefs are
dead one died 15 years ago
The other 10 years ago They were
Scar faced Charlie & Steamboat
Frank. The Modocs remind me
of the Apaches They are rather
small in stature but were built
there are several tribes of Indians
living around here.
Your devoted nephew
Elbridge.
4218
Completed

Seneca. Mo. 2/6/01
Feb. 6. 1901
My dear Uncle
I am painting
a Modoc Chief he was
in the famous Modoc
war in the lava beds
where afterwards Capt
Jack was hung.
There are only 13 Modoc
men here They remind me
very much of the Apaches
and the fellow I am
painting resembles Geronimo
a little that is his chin
these Modoc are very
industrious they chop around
and haul it to town
Ayer MS 120
Completed

to sell the Chief is
sitting for me in costume
and face painted, they
all when dressed in
costume wear a sort of
hat beaded and feathers
stuck in it.
The seem to be a very
honorable race of men.
Mr Kimbark thinks they
will let the Indian plates
rest now for a few years
and bring them out again.
They control 33 plates while
the Color type people control
21 but I get royalty on
all of them.
The Hotel I am stopping at
is a good place good
thing to eat
Your devoted nephew
Elbridge.
4218
Completed

Seneca Mo.
Quaw paw Agency
Mch. 9 1901
My dear Uncle
My wife surprised
me yesterday by coming
here and I am awfully
glad she is here as she
is company for me &
she will get some good
Indian stories here.
I have finished one picture
of Chief Yellow Hammer.
and am painting another
of him in first Modoc
costume he was in the
Modoc war.
A Seneca Chief is to sit
for me in costume.
Ayer MS 120
Completed

I sold the other two pictures
of Keokuk & Blackhawk
and think one of Yellow
Hammer is sold.
I have found out the true
history of wampum and
nearly every one who think
they know about wampum
are mistaken and was
what it really was used for.
It was in the shape of a
belt but never worn
and was used as a
sort of agreement between
two tribes each tribe in
older times had a wampum
reader and only he could
read the belt. far westward 
one time a tribe of Indians
wanted to be a peace with
the Siouxs so they sent
their wampum belt to the
Siouxs and it read We
4218
Completed

(3)
want to be at peace with you
The Siouxs made a wampum
belt and sent to
the other tribe it had on
it a picture of a Sioux with
his hand extended to shake
hands but in his other
hand held a bow and arrow
back of him which ment
we are willing to be friends
but we are always prepared
for war.
A man here who has
a good deal of Wyandotte
blood in his veins tells
me this he has a wampum
belt now more than one
hundred years old which
Ayer MS 120    3-9-01
Completed

had quite a history.
I am taking it easy
am not working hard
at all and am in
hopes to be my self
before living I am
much better
With love to you and 
Aunt Emma
Your affectionate nephew
Elbridge.
Completed

Darlington O.T.
Mch. 25. 1901.
My dear Uncle
(Excuse paper all I have)
We arrived here yesterday
and I am going to paint
all the Chiefs There I did
not get where here before
Black coyote is to sit
again. you have one of him.
I cant tell you how
much better I feel to have
my wife with me. she
is so much company
for me keeps my room
in nice order and sees
that I get proper food
to eat and if necessary
cooks her self I used
Ayer MS 120
Completed

to get so awfully lonesome
when alone The life itself
was bad enough and
it was a mistake I didn't
take her with me from the
very beginning what extra
expense there is I can
make up by doing better
work, there she is a good
writer when we were in Germany
she wrote articles for
newspapers here and some
of the other papers gave her
complimentary notions on
her writing, wish I had
shown you the articles she 
wrote that I have in my
scrap book. There she has
such fine chances to get
Indians stories from the
Indians Yellow Hammer
4218
Completed

(3) The Modoc told her
all about the Modoc war
then a Wyandott Indian told
here a lot of fine Indian
legends she is busy all
the time writing then years
ago she wrote an article
about White Swan for
Harpers Weekly which they
gave us $55.00 for the
article will come out soon
and will send you one.
Am sure she can pay
her way with me by
writing about the Indians
and am sure the Santa Fe
will give her passes as
her stories will be published,
next Winter we meant to
go along the Santa Fe
road I want to get
samples of the Toaz
Ayer MS 120 3-25-01
Completed

Pueblos the Isleta Pueblos
& the Acoma Pueblos
as well as the Pima &
Maricopa and those
Indians living in the
Grand Canon.
We are working on our book
all the time, here is how
it starts off hope it
will pleas you if not let
me know.
An Artists is forever
among the Indians
by E. A. Burbank
I left Chicago March
9th 1897 for Ft Sill O.T.
commissioned to paint
a portrait for Mr
Edmund E. Ayer of Chicago
of Chief Geronimo.
Mr Ayer has been the
Indians friend all his
life and has colleced
Completed

(5) and presented to the
Field Columbian Museum
(of which he was its first
President) the largest
collection ever got together
of American Indian curios
He also has the most
extensive library in existence
of Indian literature which
he has presented to the
Newberry library of
Chicago. The rest goes
on with my experiences.
I think it would have
been a good investment if
I had hired a good man
to act as guardian
over me just had him
watch me and manage
things am sure I could
have made $50.000 on
those Indians reproductions
Ayer MS 120 3-25-01
Completed

it make me feel bad
as I have worked so
hard all my life and
those chances dont
happen often. but am
sure I will do well on
the book I will have
some 60 five page
illustrations in it in half
tone with the owners under
each picture. I have a
lot of good interesting
stories to tell about
the Indians, and I shall
keep my eyes open and
see that some one else
dont get all the money
as was the case with
the color reproductions
it seems as though I
had a right to examine
Completed

(7) their books as according
to the commission I have
received they have done
only $12.000 worth of
business.
Now that my wife
is with me I am not
working so hard and
looking out for my health,
before I over worked and
kept on over working
forced my self to work
and then on top of it all
eating such poor
unhealthy food not
nourishing at all I
believe if kept in my
mind would have
become effected
My wife gets along
fine with the Indians
Ayer MS 120 3-25-01
Completed

she seems to like the life
think I have sold one of
Yellow Hammers portraits
I have a good customer
in Mr Butler he has bought
some 15 of my Indians
all Chiefs. The picture
I had at the Paris Exposition
is back a Navajo
you haven't any if you
want it let me know
Mr Butler may want
it she is dressed in
Navajo costume all
through. Shall be glad
to hear from you With love
to you & Aunt Emma
Your devoted nephew

Darlington.
O.T.
April. 22. 1901.
My dear Clara
Yours received
I reviewed a little
from Buffals stating
that Uncle Ed had
offered to loan 20
of his Indian pictures they asked
me to send them the
titles of 27 instead of
20 which I don't think
Uncle Ed will object
to
I am getting some
good types here.
I like it so much better
Ayer MS 120
Completed

having Tot with me I
would be a good many
dollars ahead if had had 
her with me all the time
and Taken her advice
as I see she is a good
business woman.
I sent four Modoc
Chiefs pictures to Thurber
last week Uncle Ed will
probably want one of them
I have a good customer
at Youngstown Ohio he
is buying a collection
of Indian portraits and
in the last year has
bought some fourteen
of mine.
I expect to have a
Completed

nice exhibition in Chicago
next Fall. I am not
yet my self but gaining
a little.
There is no end of material
to be obtained from these
Indians and Tot is a fine
hand to get it. I have
been so busy painting here to
fare unclear after work too
tired to do much writing
but since Tot is with me
I want to go over the
Indian field again as I
can see all the Chiefs
I can paint,
We are busy on my book
Ayer MS 120
Completed

have nearly 200 pages written
which is interesting as I
have heard so many stories
from the Indians and the
whites who have lived with
them for years. There is so much
written about the Indians that
is wrong I saw an article
the other day in a magazine
ilustrating Indians heads
painted and giving the
reasons why they paint
part of it was true but the
greater part not true.
I expect to have some
60 ilustrations in the book.
A Kansas City Star reporter
came to interview me few
days ago and he had
quite a nice article
Completed

(5)
with a portrait of my self
When will Uncle Ed return?
We probably will not be
in Chicago until Sept or Oct.
There is an Indian boy here
whose Grand father is what
is called the Caluedu man
and he starts in at Sun
down to tell stories and talks
until sun rise he has a
long stick and if any of
his listeners go to sleep he
wraps them in the head
to keep them awake, this
boy is chock full of stories
and the most wierd stories
for children, Why a goose
Ayer MS 120
Completed

eye is red why animals are
the different colors they are
and why different animals
prey on others etc etc he
is telling those stories to Tot
it is too bad Tot does not
understand short hand she
could get twice the stories
Your affectionate cousin
Elbridge.
Completed

Darlington 
O.T.
April 27, 1901.
Dear Clara
Yours received.
Yes there does seem to be
some mistake. The first
letter I received from Buffalo
man inviting me to send
some of my Indian portraits
to the Eth Dept. but in the
circular it stated that exhibits
were sent at the owners
risk and expense so I decided
not to send but was
willing to send to the to
Art department which
have done, and here the
other day I received a
letter stating Mr Ayer
Ayer MS 120
Completed

would send 20 of his pictures
and asking me for the titles
which I have sent to Buffalo
I expect it is a mistake
It would be best for Uncle
Ed to send his as his are
the most noted ones I have
painted while those I have
on hand now are only
common Indians very few
Chiefs among them.
You might write to the 
Ethnological dept in Buffalo
and ask if they reviewed a
letter direct from Uncle
Ed. I have just found
the received from
Buffalo which I enclose
to you.
Yours affectionately
Elbridge
Completed

Darlington.
O.T.
April 29. 1901
My dear Uncle
We have been here
a few weeks and I am
having fine success in
getting subjects, all the
Chiefs here have promised
to sit for me and when
I was here before only
four or five would sit
Wolf Robe the most
important chiefs of
the S. Cheyennes sits for
me this week There
Row of lodges, Wolf face
Starving Elk Three fingers
Left Hand Red Wolf
and other Chiefs are to
Ayer MS 120
Completed

sit for me. Black Coyote
& Burnt all over have
sat for two and three
portraits for me this time
you have portraits of both
I am so glad my wife
is with me I should have
had her with me all the
time She can pay her
expenses by her writing
The Chicago Post has
published two of her articles
and wants her to write
for them right away. I
sent one of the articles to
Lizzie. I am getting us
a small type writer as
then it will be better.
She is writing an article
now for a magazine
4218
Completed

(3)
I wrote you and told you
how my book would commence
have not heard from you
whether you like it or not.
I sent four Modoc
pictures to Thurbers wish
you would go in and see
them.
I am only painting Chiefs
now and will paint
them and four portraits
of each if they will sit
for that many.
Clara will explain to
you about the pictures to
be sent to the Buffalo pan
Expo" I filled a blank
out for 20 for the Art
4-29-01 Ayer MS 120
Completed

department but they thought
they had room for only six
I received a letter from
McNeil yesterday he paid
me for the man bonnet
he thought possibly he
might get out West this
Summer and do some work
among the Indians.
While we are in this part
of the country I want to
try and get a portrait of
Quana Parker the Comanche
head Chief also Ah-pe-ah-Tong
Big-Tree and To-wah-ka-ne-Jim
a Wichita Chief and a
man with a history.
I have met him before
but he was too busy
to sit for me.
Completed

(5)
shall be glad to hear from
you. We want to try and
get my book out this
Fall but I have got to
be Sharp and see that
I dont get beat out of
most of the profits.
The Indian reproductions
was such a loss to see
and mismanaged so by
my self that in the future
I am going to look out for
my self more The trouble
was I had too much
confidence it seems as
though I had a right
to look at their books
as it is now I take their
4-29-01 Ayer MS 120
Completed

word for the business done
which seems to me is not

Your affectionate nephew

Darlington. O.T.
May 5. 1901
My dear Uncle
Yours of April
18th received
There has been some
missunderstanding in
regard to the pictures
to be sent to Buffalo,
Clara will tell you
about it.
Hamlin Garland is here
now he spoke of the
articles my wife has
written for the papers
& complimented her
Ayer MS 120
Completed

She has some nice stories
written for publication
I wonder now how I
ever stood it among
the Indians alone, it
would have been money
in my pockets to have
had her and my
health would have been
better, she sees that
I get good food to
eat, if she has to cook
it her self and looks
after me, a man
need his wife with
him on all occasions
he can work better.
4218
Completed

I am no hand to call on
people but here my
wife has resisted in
my going out the
result in have not
some nice people.
I am sorry to say she
has the malaria and
we thought it best for
her to go home for
two or three weeks. I
have passes there &
back for her The Santa Fe
people told me any
time I wanted passes
over their road for
my self & wife They
Completed

would give them to us.
I am painting now
Chief Wolf Robe he
has with out any exception
the finest head
I ever saw on an Indian
the finest type.
I am making some
red chalk sketches of
the Indians which I
think will sell well
as they can be sold
cheap and all are
drawn from life
I can make half a 
dozen in a day
Completed

(5) Mr Garland was very
enthusiastic over them.
I note what you say
in regard to my book
I will be very careful
and not mention only
things I am sure of, but
the book is to be devoted
to see experiences among
the Indians principally the Indians
do not know that I
am gathering up such a
book. The book
will give the side of
an Indian different
from what has ever
been written
5-5-01 Ayer MS 120
Completed

it is a big job and I
must be sharp and see
that I get my share of
the profits.
All the Chiefs here are
to sit for me including
Left Hand who now

return to Chicago wish
you would look at
my Modoc pictures
you may want one
I expect Mr Butler
of Youngstown to buy

Completed

When am through here

Maratta has painted a

Exposition.
Am glad you and

having such a nice
time. I saw an article

Darlington O. T.
May 9. 1901.
Dear Clara
Yours received.
I have sent word to
Buffalo there they can have
20 of my Indian pictures for
the Ethno department.
Tot was sick with malaria
so thought it best for her to
go home I am so lonesome
for her dont know what to do
I cant understand now how I ever
stood it among from her before
she will be gone only two or
three weeks
In regard to the advertisement I
dont care so much for that as
it dont seem to bring in much
money. seems to me I have
had too much advertisement
and too little money.
I made such an awful
Ayer MS 120
Completed

mistake in not handling those
Indian reproductions my self as
could have made a lot of money
out of it as it is I allowed
others to handle them and I
made but little and my being
so nervous has made me feel
very bad, I have been so awfully
selfish where Tot has been
concerned noted as though I had
no wife but how often I will
appreciate her I never knew Tot was
such a good business woman until
lately and now I see if I had
always taken her advise I today
would be much happier and 
better off financially Sound Told
you I received a letter from Uncle
Ed from Rome.
Your affectionate cousin
Elbridge.
Completed

Darlington. O.T.
June 20. 1901.
My dear Uncle Ed
Mr Dorsey has just been
over here to see me and I enjoyed
his visit, I wish I had met
him when I first went out among
the Indians he is full of valuable
hints & information in regard to the
Indians I went at the Indians
sort of blind all I cared for was
their portraits but it is not too
late now my intention is to visit
every tribe in America and I just
feel like doing the thing over again
have my wife with me and she attend
to the writing get all the information
she can form the Indians why they
do this and that and get the
reason of every design on their
clothing etc, this all would be
too much for me as my
Ayer MS 120
Completed

time would be taken up in painting,
my wife is a good writer and
has received some nice compliments
from the Chicago papers. I sent
you a catg or two. her writing
would enable us to get passes
in all Western roads and instead
of its being an expense to me it
would be making money.
She is not with me now as there
was sickness in the family and
she was not well in account
of the trial she has been through
but it has all passed now.
I have got some good portraits
of Chief Wolf Robe S. Cheyenne
and other Chiefs Have been making
some red chalk sketches of the
Indians and have had good
success selling them I can sell
them cheap as it takes but a
short time to make them
4218
Completed

I am not well at all, all
run down I worked too hard and
then trouble has been a little too
much for me but am taking it
easier here after will only work
4 1/2 hours a day which is long
enough and then take a two
months vacation and paint forty
portraits a year that is enough
as it is very trying on ones nerves
Mr Dorsey has had a profitable
trip he tells me run across some
fine things for the museums.
He is anxious for the museum
to buy a lot of my Indian portraits
I wish it could be brought about.
I would be willing to let them go
for $100.00 each.
The Lake must look full and
I know you enjoy it.
There is not a King in Enhinn
living on that ever did live
Ayer MS 120 6-20-01
Completed

that enjoys life any more than
you and I dare say as much
Well if I had been more careful in
my life I would be extremely happy
Today but then there are many
years ahead of me to make up.
Did you see Chief Yellow Hammers
Portrait in Thurbers? There are three
of them he is a Modoc and took
a prominent part in the Modoc
War. I want to remain here until
paint the rest of the Arapahoe &
Cheyenne Chiefs here.
With love to you & Aunt Emma
Your affectionate nephew
Elbridge.
Completed

[[THE CORDOVA
New York Ave., Near Beach
Atlantic City, N.J.
SERAPH F. LILLIG - letterhead]]
July 18 1901
My dear Uncle
Am sorry I did not get to see you at
Seneca Lake.
My wife and I came
here yesterday and I
am glad we came
the salt in and sea
baths & rest is helping
me. I have worked so
hard among the Indians
& have food to eat
there I am in bad
health that is my
nervous system.
I thought I was made
of iron.
Completed

(2)
[[THE CORDOVA
New York Ave., Near Beach
Atlantic City, N.J.
SERAPH F. LILLIG
_______________190 - letterhead]]
but now I see that
it is putting money in
the bank to take a vacation
over a year something I
rarely ever did.
I am so afraid that
I can not continue
with my work among the
Indians in account of
those reproductions it has
hurt the sale of the originals
Thurber tells me he never
has any call for them
now. I was so in
hopes to carry out my
plan of painting Indians
from each tribe in
7-18-01
Completed

(3)
[[THE CORDOVA
New York Ave., Near Beach
Atlantic City, N.J.
SERAPH F. LILLIG
_______________190 - letterhead]]
America but if they do
not sell I will have
to give it up.
It is a pity that I
am not a business
man but I am not
and therefore loose lots
of money Those people
who had my Indian
reproductions in charge
should have done the
fair thing by me
they claim. they have
done only $10,000 worth
of business. which is
hard for me to believe
as the whole country has
7-18-01
Completed

(4)
[[THE CORDOVA
New York Ave., Near Beach

been flooded with my
Indians.
Well I have been unlucky
but in the future will
look out. I will have
an exhibition this Fall
at Thurbers and can see

I feel awfully bad
Uncle Ed at what
has happened in the past
year but I was anything
but a well man
and made a mountain
out of a mole hill
and my wife and I
have suffered more than
I can tell. We are
7-18-01

[[THE CORDOVA

SERAPH F. LILLIG

stopping at a little
Hotel here very reasonable
and meant to remain
here until I am well
am sleeping better &

My wife had an

about Chief Burnt-all-over

Philadelphia. Penna.
Dec 7 1901.
My dear Uncle
It was a good
move my coming on
until my Indian pictures
here, they are attracting a
good deal of attention.
Mr Cuney who is manager
of the Museum here is much
interested in them and
wants them all for the
Museums, they tell me
that what he wants he
generally gets. Mr
Wannamaker is very much
interested in Indians &
Indian curios he gave 
Mr Cuney $20,000 to buy
Indian curios with so
he bought a car load
Completed

of curios. He wants to
see all the Indian pictures
I have on had so I have
sent to Chicago to have
them all sent to me
Mr Maratta is here and
helping me to sell them
he is a better business man
than I am.
Mr Holmes has written
to have me send the
pictures to Washington
I met Mr Maran the 
Artist he comes to see
my pictures often &
likes them and is trying
to have them all go to
the museum.
They have a very good
museum here Wannamaker
bought a collection of
Catlins pictures and some of
4218
Completed

Julius Scatts for the Museums
Maratta and I are invited
to a Dinner Monday to
meet prominent people
and the University faculty
to talk over the Indian
pictures. I hope something
will come of it
There are three tribes of
Indians here Navajo
Ojibways & Iroquois
all in full costume will
make some red chalk
drawings of them.
Your affectionate nephew
Elbridge.
3330 Walnut St.
12-7-01
Completed

Philadelphia Penna.
Dec. 10. 1901 12/10/01
My dear Uncle
The prospects are good
for my selling all my
Indian portraits to the
Museum her.
They have telegraphed to
the different places where
my pictures are paying
all charges on them and
some of them are in
San Francisco
Mr Maran the Artist
tells me that Mr
Cuney the Curator of 
the Museum gets what
he wants and he wants
these pictures very much
As soon as the pictures
Completed

arrive they are to be placed,
on exhibition at the Club
here and invitations sent
out to prominent people
to inspect them this is
at the Museums expense
They are to have a fine
feast, the invitations are
to be made for the occasion
Maratta is to make them.
If the pictures are purchased
They are to hang in the
picture hall if the Museum.
Mr Cuney has had
some prominent Artists to
look at the pictures such
as Maran and Aiken
and have spoken well
of them. Mr Cuney is
about as big a crank
in the Indians as I have
met was at his residence
to Dinner last evening
Completed

(3) and we talked Indian
from the time I arrived
until mid night.
I hope the deal will
go through.
I received a letter from
Prof Holmes and he
wants me to bring them
all on the Washington
he told me he would
show them at the Club
then afterwards in the
Museums, but I hope they
will be sold her.
There are some good
types of Indians here
The Ojibways are at
the Spartmans show
here and Wannamaker
has some Iroquois in
his store making Indian
curios.
12-10-01
Completed

I have been making
some drawings of them.
I am getting over my
nervousness gradually
I can stand it all
right out West with
the Indians if take good
care of my self and not
over work.
The Museum here ownes
a fine portrait of Cushing
with his Zuni costume on
painted by Aiken
The way the Museums are
buying Indian costumes
and also dealers in curios
I am afraid there will
not be any costumes
left among the Indians
the curator of the New
York Museum was here to
see me he says in case
my pictures are not
bought here he wants
Completed

(5) to figure on them.
Of course I would like
to have Field Museum
own them and I am
sure in 50 years from
now they will regret
that some other Museum
ownes them.
Am very glad we came
here I should have brought
the pictures East before.
With love to you and
Aunt Emma
Your affectionate nephew
Elbridge.
3330 Walnut St.
12-10-01
Completed

Philadelphia Penna.
Dec. 12. 1901. 12/12/01
My dear Uncle
Yours received
I am very much obliged
to you for the letter
to Mr Wannamaker
he is out of the city at
present hope he will
return in time for the
reception.
I am quite sure some
good results will come of
my visit here, Today
a party representing the
Hyde exploring Co came
to me and wanted
to know the lowest
figure I would take for
all my Indian portraits
Completed

I could not give him
a definate answer until
the Museum has a chance
there are now four
parties figuring on getting
my pictures and I hope
one of the four will get
them.
I am making red chalk
drawings of the Indians
here and some larger
ones in black for
reproducing.
Maratta here is a good
friend he is a better
business man than me
I have taken all of my
Indian pictures away
from the Show, they
were not Insured and they
kept putting me off
4218
Completed

so finally Maratta went
to them and he says
unless the Insurance
papers were handed to
him the next day the
pictures would be removed
so the next day we
took them out and
they now are in the
vault in the Museum.
Mr Cuney is a fine man
and a good friend he
is doing all he can to
have these pictures
hang in the Museum.
The Ojibways here are
all from Canada They
are a good type among
them is an old man
whose Uncle was a
friend of Longfellow
12-12-01
Completed

and gave? him the story
of Hiawatha.
If I sell my Indian
portraits I will make
up in a measure what
I lost on the reproductions
and if I do not sell
them I will keep at
my work among the
Indians but this Indian
craze will result in
buying all the Indian
clothes & war bonnets
the Indians have.
It would be nice if
an Artist could borrow
Indians clothes from the
Museums & take them
West with him
Thanking you again for the 
letter to Mr Wannamaker
Am Yours affectionate
nephew Elbridge
3330 Walnut. St.
Completed

Philadelphia Penna.
Dec. 26. 1901.
My dear Uncle
Mr Stewart Culin
who is Director of the
Museum here will call and
see you this week. I
have given him a
letter of introduction to
you.
You will like him
he is a fine man
and a scholar he has
written a good
deal on the Indian
and is at present
writing an extensive
book on the Indian
games.
Completed

My pictures 120 unclear
all are hung in the
Museum now The
board meets Friday
and it looks as though
I would sell them all
They that is Mr Culin
wants all of them I
have given him a price
which he is satisfied
with, the price is
reasonable.
My pictures are listed
at $150.00 and $200.00
each and it would be
better for him not to
know what you paid
for your pictures in
case the subject
should be mentioned
4218
Completed

I am anxious for him
to see your picture
that is your portrait.
I am feeling better
and hope it will
not be long before
I can be among the
Indians again and
finish my work &
carry out my plans.
With love to you and
Aunt Emma and a
Happy New Year to
you both
Your affectionate nephew
Elbridge.
3330 Walnut St.
12-26-01
Completed

Philadelphia. Pa.
Jan. 12. 1902.
My dear Uncle
Mr Culin has returned
and says he had a
most unclear? and
enjoyable visit with you.
Enclose send you a
clipping.
It has not been settled
yet whether my pictures
are to remain in the
Museum but the prospects
are good.
I received a letter from
a very wealthy man
who writes me that if
the Museum does not
take the pictures he wants
to negotiate for them
Mr Thomas Eakins
Completed

has finished my portraits
be painted one of my
Indian portraits on the
background in the picture
every one like the picture
it hangs now in the
University Club, he made
me a present of the
portrait but he said he
wished at my death
the portrait would go to
some Museum that had
a collection of my Indian
portraits.
I am growing slowly
in health and as soon as
am all right again I
want to continue my
work among the Indians
until it is finished.
Your affectionate nephew.
Elbridge.
3330 Walnut. St.
4218
Completed

Philadelphia. Pa.
Feb. 4. 1902.
My dear Uncle
I have succeeded
in selling 100 of my
Indians portraits to
a man in Ohio.
so the Museum here
has lost them which
Mr Culin will regret
very much.
I got a good price
for them considering
that so many
squaws were among
Completed

as I want to complete
what I started out to
do.
I have on hand now
some 33 pictures.
Your affectionate
nephew
Elbridge.
3330 Walnut. St.
4218
Completed

them.
The party bought them
with out frames
I thought thirteen
of my pictures were
missing but all
have turned up except
two.
We will be leaving
soon now for
Chicago. I am
feeling better
and am in hopes to
get back to work
soon among the
Indians
Completed

[[TOD HOUSE
YOUNGSTOWN, OHIO
AMERICAN AND EUROPEAN -- letterhead]]
Feb. 22. 1902. FEB 27 Ans'd -- stamp
My dear Uncle
I dont know
whether I Told you about
the Indian pictures I sold
I sold 106 for $10.600
with out frame I have
left now 25 pictures
which hang in the Museum
in Philadelphia.
Mr Butler of Youngstown
bought the pictures he has
now 118 of my pictures
he is in the iron business
here and used to work
for Mr John V. Ayer in 1863
he knew Grandpa your
Father he is very much
interested in the Indians.
Completed

and has quite a library
on the Indians, he is anxious
to meet you he is in
Chicago now and then
I will give him an 
introduction to you.
I am here painting his
portrait, my wife and
I are invited out so much
here that we can not
accept all the invitations
we met Seargie Manning
the other evening his sister
lives here.
I want to get out
among the Indians again
just as soon as can.
Your affectionate nephew
Elbridge
4218
Completed

Rosebud Agency
S. Dak. NOV 11 1902 -- stamp
Nov. 5. 1902.
My dear Uncle
I am hear with
the Brule Sioux working
hard. There are some
fine types here and
some noted Chiefs still
living. old Chief
TwoStrikes is sitting
for me now he is
82 years old he has
caused the Government
a good deal of trouble
he took part in the
Custer fight.
I am making a
Completed

red chalk drawing
every day.
I am feeling much
better have a good
appetite sleep well
and taking good care
of my self take long
walks every day.
I have a nice place
to eat and sleep
and I am glad I
am right where I
am, our book is
finished ready for
the publisher and I
am in hopes to do
well with it, but
it is the last writing
4218
I have? to do.
Chief Crow Dog is here
he is the Indian who
killed Spotted Tail.
Chief Hollow Horn is
here also he has the
reputation of being the
finest specimen of
an Indian living.
I am so glad I
am away from
Chicago and out
West where I
belong.
Shall be glad to
hear from you
With love to you
and Aunt Emma
Your affection nephew
Elbridge.
Completed

Rosebud. S. Dak.
Nov. 28. 1902.
My Dear Uncle DEC 10 1902 -- stamp
Yours at hand.
this is the best place
I have been to yet
for Indians There
are more noted
Chiefs here and better
types than any place
I have been to yet.
Chief Spotted Tails
old squaw is living
am going to make a
portrait of her. every
Indian I paint I make
a few red chalk
drawings from
Completed

some of the drawing
you can have for
$10.00 each and those
that I am making now
will have to charge $15.00
each for as am
putting twice the amount
of work on them you will
like them better. I am
taking it easier. work
4 1/2 hours every day
then I take long walks
and exercise a good
deal and am careful
about the food I eat.
We have a good place
to eat and nice
comfortable room
all togeather it is
about the healthiest
4218
place have been in except
at Nes Pilem Wash.
Expect to remain here
all Winter.
Our book is all
ready now for the
Publishers my wife
is attending to it
which was a good
deal of work it has
been rewritten several
times and re type written
twice, it has been handed
to the Publishers and
they told my wife that
it was a very important
mms? and wished
to read it over carefully
the mms? has been
shown to good writer
Completed

in Chicago he read it
all through and pronounced
it way above the
average of books and
did not see why we
could not do well
with it. I hope so.
I will send you some
drawings soon
Am glad Aunt
Emma has recovered
With best wishes
Your affect. nephew
Elbridge.
P.S. An Indian I am
painting has on of those
old deer horn saddles
which are very rare.
Completed

Rosebud. S. Dak.
Dec. 22. 1902.
My dear Uncle
Yours received DEC 27 1902 -- stamp
I have a lot of
red chalk drawings on
hand and will send
them all to you right
after xmas, you will
like the red drawings
better than any drawings
I have made as have
carried them further.
I am having a hard
time to get these Indians
to sit for an oil
portrait the trouble is
they all have been pretty
busy and as a result
Completed

they have some money
but pretty soon this
money will be gone
then I will get them
have got several oil
paintings started and
only one finished, they
would commence to sit
then go to work but
I could keep them long
enough to finish the
red drawings so have
lots of them. There are
more Chiefs here than
any place I have been
to.
the Indian tradre here
has got a genuine Buffalo
skin Tepee painted he
also has a cloth Tepee
4218
with the history of the
Brule Sioux painted on
it. The skin Tepee can
be bought, he has it
packed away in a
shed, seems to me it
would be an addition
to the Field Museum
all set up.
We have plenty of Winter
here there is so much
snow that the stage
coach not get through
Today.
I am getting along
all right getting over
my nervousness, taking
lots of exercise bath
out doors and indoors
but the food is not
as I would like it
pork three times every
Completed

every day nearly. I Told
the waiter this evening
that when the proprietor
died he ought to be placed
in a hogs hide coffin
buried in a hog pen and
hog bristles strewed over
his grave.
I probably will remain
here till next Spring
Wishing you all a
happy xmas
Your affectionate nephew
Elbridge.
Completed

JAN 3-1903 -- Stamp
Rosbud. S. Dak.
Dec 26 - 1902
My dear Uncle
I send you
tomorrow by express
40 red chalk drawings
12 of these are drawings
like the ones you first
bought of me the rest
are a more finished
portrait, but you can
have them at the
same price $10.00 each
Thurber sells them
for $15.00 & $20.00 each
Im having a hard
Completed

time to get the Indians
to pose as the weather
is so cold they no
not come in as often
as they did but I
will remain here until
half all the important
Chiefs.
Wishing you all a
Happy New Year
Your affectionate
nephew
Elbridge.
4218
Completed

JAN 9 - 1903 -- stamp
Rosebus. S. Dak.
Jan. 5. 1903.
My dear Uncle
Your received
and glad you like
the red drawings.
I have got These
Indians on the run
now They all are
often me to paint
them I have not
advanced the price give
them 50 cts an hour
to sit for red drawings
and $ 2.00 a day where
they sit 4 1/2 hours,
but I have a plan
Completed

where I can keep them
with me a week to
paint them. I give
them $1.50 a day
then pay for their board
and lodging which
amounts to $4.00 a
week they & furnish
one or two houses
with hog for a week
I have to do this
as there is no grazing
here for stock of any
kind with in six miles
of the Agency.
I am careful in
selecting Indians
for red drawings
in the red drawings
I try to select
Indians with a good
4218
Completed

strong face but in
the oil paints I
intend to paint only
Chiefs and Indians of
not. Am glad I
took up the red
drawings.
I made a red drawing
of a very noted Chief
Today a book has
been written about
him it is Chief Picket
Pin alias Chief Bear Eagle.
he is about as Lonely
a man as I ever saw.
He is to sleep with me
to night that is he will
sleep on the floor. I
asked him if he snored
he said no. no he
wanted to know if I did
Completed

I told him no but I
said the man who
sleeps in the other bed
snores terribly the Indian
laughed. I will get
every one of these Chiefs
here before leaving.
I wish I could have
been present xmas
but I think it will
be a long time before
going East.
I have made a
red drawing of Chief
Yellow Hair he and
Chief Spotted Tail and
Red Cloud are the
three principal Chiefs
Completed

of the Sioux nation.
Yellow Hair is to sit
for an oil portrait.
Thurber has written me
to send him some
red drawings but I
think it wise to
make them for you
at $10.00 and will
gladly make you 150
more and will be
careful and not
send you more than
one of same Indian.
sometimes I make
a front view and
profile of same Indian
but as a rule make
1-5-03
Completed

more profiles, as a profile
seems to show an
Indians strongest character
Thurber has written
me he has a pretty
good offer for two
of my Indian portraits
have written him to
accept the offer as
they are to unsaleable
portraits on of them being
a Squaw.
I am getting better
all the time taking
good care of my self
take long walks
twice a day.
Your affectionate
nephew
Elbridge.
Completed

Rosebud. S. Dak. JAN 21 1903 -- stamp
Jan. 15. 1903
My dear Uncle Ed
Yours of Jan 9th
received and glad to
hear from you.
I am painting in oil
right along now
have painted a portrait
of Chief Picket Pin
and made two red
drawings of him he
is a noted character
a sharp shrewd man
when the Indians
left the reservation
here several years ago
Completed

Picket Pin remained
and he tore down the
log houses belonging to
the Indians that had
deserted them and sold
the logs to the Agency
and white people, when
the Indians returned They
complained that their
houses had been destroyed
so the Government built
them new houses.
I have a fine subject
coming to morrow Chief
Sky Bull have painted
one portrait of him and
made two red drawings
but am going to paint
a profile of him. I
make these Indians
take of their shifts
4218
Completed

so they are bare to
the waste. Chief He Dog came
to see me to day he is
going to sit for me
and I saw Crow Dog
the other day he will sit
also he killed Spotted Tail
he was jealous of him
Several of the Indians
called a counsel to see
who would kill Spotted
Tail and drew cuts and 
it fell to Crow Dog
He shot him a half mile from
here as Spotted Tail
was riding his horse.
Nearly all the Indians
do not like Crow Dog.
I have thought that
possibly it might be a
Completed

good plan for me to go
to Alaska next July and
visit the different tribes
there, there are five distinct
tribes there. Mr P. B.
Ware told me that any
time I wished to go he
would give me transportation
there and back.
I also think it a wise
idea to turn the pictures
over to you as you say
my reputation will unclear
through your collection.
I would not think of
going home for any
length of time, the
rest of my life will
Completed

be devoted among the
Indians and I have
a life work ahead of
me in painting and
making red drawings, am
going all over my
old tracks again principally
to make red drawings.
I want to make quite
a number of red drawings
of each tribe to show the
character and type.
The cold weather does
not bother me at all
and am nicely fixed
and gaining in health
I find that 4 1/2 hours
work every day is enough
1-15-03
Completed

for me then I am out
doors the rest of the time
Have you a Sioux dictionary?
I have just bought me one
am studying Sioux.
There are two very
fine Sioux artists here
I have a picture by
a Sioux very finely painted
on a cloth some two
feet square it can be
bought for #3.00 if you
wish it will send it to
you.
If I went to Alaska
next July would remain
there until finished up
with all the different
tribes there if do not
go will visit the
different Sioux tribes
Completed

there is a good type of
a Yankton Sioux here
am going to make a
red drawing of him
The Yanktons are very
civilized but this fellow
is not he works here
at the Agency.
I shall be glad to
hear from you when
you are in Europe
and will write you
every week.
Your affectionate
nephew
Elbridge.
Completed

JAN 29 1903 -- stamp
Rosebud. S. Dak.
Jan. 22. 1903.
My dear Uncle
I have a checking
account with the
Illinois Trust and
Savings Bank and if
you just as soon wish
you would deposit
the $400.00 on my checking
account in the
Illinois Trust & Savings
Bank my current
account unclear book
is with the bank as
I leave it there.
I have finished a
Completed

picture in oil of Chief
Sky Bull and Today
will finish and oil
of Chief Picket Pin.
I have two red
drawings of Picket Pin
I have to watch him
as he is such a sharp
fellow he always gets
the best of me but he
is a good reliable man.
Yesterday Chief Lance
called on me he is
a fine type he is to
sit for a portrait in
oil, all the Indians
I paint now I do
not allow them to
have anything on
that belongs to a 
white man make
4218
Completed

them take off their
shirts and paint their
bodies as well as their
face, it seems the paint
on their bodies is more
symbolical than the
paint on their faces.
Picket Pin has two
big blotches of red paint
on his brest indicating
wounds he received
from Pawnee Indians
while he says the
paint on his face is
to look pretty, of course
all Indians are not
this way.
When warm weather
comes Chief Two
Strikes will sit for
me to finish his picture
Completed

his right Indian name
is He-Knocks-off-two
but years ago the
interpreter translated it
to the Government as
Two Strikes.
We are having nice
weather here not very
colder than in Chicago.
With love to you and
Aunt Emma.
Your affectionate nephew
Elbridge.
P.S. Yesterday when Lance
called Picket Pin was sitting
Lance pointed his finger at
him and said that man has
no right to paint up so much and
wear that feather he never
has done anything he never
killed any one etc they
both laughed. Lance was
jocking.
Completed

Rosebud. S. Dak.
Jan 28 1903
My dear Uncle
Yours of Jan 21 received.
I have only finished
four oil portraits but
I have several more
started. I would have
had several finished
but the Indians disappointed
me in coming
but they are coming now
all right I have 
several red drawings and
as soon as I get some
more will send them
Completed

to the office as
you suggest.
I will send all the
paintings to the office
also.
I hardly care to have
another exhibition
at Thurber as it is 
rather exhausive and I 
am sure I can dispense
of them to private individuals
even if I only need
a few the pictures will
be all the more
valuable in later
years.
The weather has turned
cold again.
I would send what
oil portraits I now
have but they are not
4218
Completed

dry enough to
varnish out.
wishing you and
Aunt Emma a
happy voyage
Your affectionate nephew
Elbridge.
Completed

Rosebud. S. Dak.
Feb. 15. 1903.
My dear Uncle
Yours received
It is all right in regard
to the money.
I am getting along
all right, have no trouble
at all now in getting
the Indians to sit for
me, they bother me
now to sit, am
painting my second
portrait of Chief High
Pipe have made two
red drawings of him
Completed

am painting him with
Chief Spotted Tails buck
skin coat of? which a
white man loaned to
me.
This week Chief He Dog
comes to sit for me he
is a fine type and a
genuine Indian he is
very anxious to sit for
me will make two
red drawings of him and
paint two portraits.
I have no trouble in
getting all the Indian
clothes I want here
so many of the white
4218
Completed

(3)
people have Indian curios
here and the Indians have
quite a good deal them
selves on account of the
Indian dance they have
every week.
Do you remember the
Navajo blanket my
Mother has it is one you
gave to your Father. I
have copyied it for
Mr Hubbell it is one
of the finest blankets I
ever saw.
Soon as I get some
more pictures will send
Them to your Office.
2-15-03
Completed

I want to go to Pine
Ridge Agency again and
get some more portraits
of Red Cloud also some
red drawings of him, there
are several other Sioux
Agencys not far from
here different bands of
the Sioux that I will
visit.
We are having nice Winter
weather.
With love to you and
Aunt Emma
Your affectionate nephew.
Elbridge.
Completed

Rosebud. S. Dak.
April. 12. 1903.
My dear Uncle
I am getting along
all right am gaining
in regard to nervousness
am taking good care of
my self and working
just hard enough to
not over do.
Have not sent any
pictures to your Office
yet. I have a lot of
Indian frames packed away
frames that Mr Butler
did not take in the
pictures he bought of me
so I guess I will send
the pictures to Harvard
and have my Father
put them in the frames
Completed

and you can choose what
ever you want of the
pictures at Harvard or
they can be sent framed
to your Office. I have
quite a number of red
drawings.
Have no trouble to get
all the Indian I want
to painted, but the most
noted Chiefs here have
not come so could
finish their pictures but
now that the weather
is warmer they will come
have finished three good
portraits of Chief He-Dog
painted and fixed up in
Indian style am now
painting One Star a
good type.
4218
Completed

I hope to be able to keep
on with this work and
guess I can all right.
I hope you and Aunt
Emma visited Rothenburg
am sure you will be more
than unclear.
I have been thinking
seriously of painting a
portrait of He-Dog
standing full life size
on a cannon? 8 feet
long he has a complete
Indian costume from head
to feet, am sure the pictures
would attract attention
and some day would sell.
Those Indians still keep
up their old customs of
dancing every Friday
night it is call the
Omaha dance.
